patterns: Can you please tell me more?
In details, please.
I would like to know more of this matter.
responses: Sure, but can you be more specific on what type of info?
What aspect would you like to know more about?
Can you be more specific in which type of info you want to find out?

patterns: How you could help me?
What you can do?
What help you provide?
How you can be helpful?
What support is offered
responses: I can guide you through some cardiovascular diseases numbers and testings
Offering support for cardiovascular diseases prediction.

patterns: How to check cardiovascular disease?
Open cardiovascular disease prediction module
Give me a prediction of my health state
List all cardiovascular disease predictions with my data
Do I have a cardiovascular disease?
Can you do the testing for me?
responses: I need you to provide some data first.
I'd love to help, but you need to tell me more about yourself.

patterns: What are the warning signs of cardiovascular disease?
What are some of the risk factors for heart disease?
What are the symptoms of cardiovascular disease?
Do all cardiovascular diseases have the same symptoms?
responses: The conventional risk factors include high cholesterol, high blood pressure, obesity, diabetes, and tobacco use or second hand smoke
The likelihood of an individual developing cardiovascular disease is influenced by some factors such as genetic make‐up, gender, little exercise, overweight, high cholesterol and blood pressure
The symptoms of cardiovascular disease include smoking, raised blood cholesterol, raised blood pressure, physical inactivity, obesity, and diabetes

patterns: What is the most important risk factor for cardiovascular disease?
What causes heart attacks?
responses: The ‘classical’ risk factors for cardiovascular disease include smoking, raised blood cholesterol, raised blood pressure, physical inactivity, obesity, and diabetes
Cardiovascular disease is caused by frequent smoking, high blood pressure, high cholesterol level, high blood sugar, obesity and physical inactivity.

patterns: How can individuals reduce their risk of cardiovascular disease?
What are some advice to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease
How do you prevent cardiovascular disease?
responses: Some of the detrimental effects can be counteracted by changes in behaviour, such as taking more exercise, stopping smoking, maintaining a healthy bodyweight, and eating a varied and well‐balanced diet.
Heart attacks can be perceived as mild pain or discomfort, including pressure, squeezing, tightness, fullness or pain.

patterns: Is heart disease a man’s disease?
Are men at greater risk of heart disease than women?
Between men and women, which has a higher chance of having cardiovascular disease?
responses: Heart disease is far from being solely a man’s disease, but it is more common in men.
Heart disease is more common in men than in women, but the prevalence increases with age in both sexes so that the difference reduces after the age of around 50–60 years
Men are more likely to die from heart disease than women.

patterns: How can weight loss reduce cardiovascular risk?
Why is being physically active important in reducing cardiovascular disease risk?
Why do I need to be fit in order to lessen my chance of having a heart disease?
Can exercise really make your heart stronger?
responses: Regular physical activity can reduce the risk of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease by improving lipid levels, and lowering blood pressure.
Studies of patients undergoing bariatric surgery demonstrate very clearly that weight loss reduces the risk of cardiovascular disease as well as type 2 diabetes and cancer

patterns: How is cholesterol linked with heart disease?
What part does cholesterol play in coronary heart disease?
Why is being obese a risk factor for cardiovascular disease?
Does being overweight increase the risk of heart disease?
responses: High cholesterol levels are associated with increased risk of heart disease and stroke.
High levels of cholesterol may increase risk of heart disease, diabetes, or stroke.
Being overweight increases the chance of having a heart attack.

patterns: What's the Link Between Smoking and Heart Disease?
Is there any link between smoking and cardiovascular disease?
Is heart disease more common among smokers?
responses: Smoking is a major cause of atherosclerosis, a disease in which plaque builds up inside your arteries.
the nicotine in smoke causes less oxygen to the heart, higher blood pressure and heart rate, more blood clotting and damage to cells that line coronary arteries and other blood vessels.

patterns: What cardiovascular diseases can alcohol cause?
How can alcohol damage the cardiovascular system?
Is there any relation between alcohol and heart disease?
What are the cardiovascular risks associated with drinking alcohol?
responses: In the long-term, drinking above the guidelines can lead to on-going increased heart rate, high blood pressure, weakened heart muscle and irregular heartbeat.
Alcohol can cause heart attacks and strokes.
Drinking too much alcohol can raise the levels of some fats in the blood (triglycerides). It can also lead to high blood pressure, heart failure and an increased calorie intake.

patterns: Is growth during childhood important in terms of cardiovascular disease risk?
Are big and fat kids at greater risk of developing cardiovascular disease in later life?
Are small babies more likely to have cardiovascular disease?
responses: Excessive gain in weight or BMI in childhood is important to determine cardiovascular disease.
Adult body mass index (BMI) is positively related to birthweight, meaning a fatter baby is more likely to have some form of heart disease than a smaller one.

patterns: Can stress cause heart disease?
Are changes in lifestyle becoming less important as treatment for cardiovascular disease?
Is lifestyle during adulthood important in causing cardiovascular disease?
responses: Cohort studies have shown that adult risk factors such as stress add to, and in some studies multiply, the effects of adverse early life exposures
Encouraging changes to lifestyle can prevent heart disease without the side effects associated with surgery and drug therapy
A stressful lifestyle can increase the risk of heart disease, although we still do not know how this happens.

patterns: What is the relation between inflammation and the risk of heart disease?
What causes the type of inflammation associated with increased risk of heart disease?
Can markers of inflammation be used to identify people at risk of heart disease?
responses: Researchers have found that people with high blood levels of C‐reactive protein, which indicates underlying levels of inflammation, are more likely to develop heart disease and stroke than those with lower levels of this protein.
Some researchers suggests inflammatory cells are recruited to the sites of developing atherosclerotic plaques in response to deposits of cholesterol or oxidised lipid products on the artery wall.
It has been suggested that prolonged inflammation of the arteries may be one of several factors that contribute to atherosclerosis (narrowing and hardening of the arteries)

patterns: Can inflammation be reduced by drugs or diet?
What can I do to reduce inflammation?
Is reducing inflammation possible with proper treatment?
responses: There are a number of pharmacological agents available to reduce inflammation, but we need further research to predict their ability to reduce cardiovascular risk.
Some aspects of the diet seem to influence the inflammatory response.
Drug treatment to lower levels of inflammation has been shown to reduce the risk of heart disease

patterns: Do antioxidant nutrients reduce the risk of heart disease?
Is it true that certain vegetables contain substances that might be good for the heart?
What is so good about fruit and vegetables?
Should we be focusing on healthy dietary patterns such as eating fruits and vegetables for reducing heart disease risk?
responses: There is a considerable body of evidence that has shown diets rich in fruit, vegetables, and other plant foods to be associated with a reduced risk of a number of diseases, including high blood pressure, obesity, heart disease, and stroke
Fruit and vegetables collectively contain a wide range of nutrients, including vitamins with antioxidant properties, which are important to the body's immune system

Free radical damage has been implicated as a factor in the development of heart disease and stroke, and a number of antioxidant nutrients found in fruits and vegetables are important in the body’s defence systems

patterns: Are medicines a contributor to heart disease?
Will taking drugs reduce the risk of heart disease?
Will taking drugs like reduce the risk of heart disease?
Are we able to prevent or cure heart disease with drugs?
responses: Some drugs like aspirin may be helpful for patients who have already had a heart attack, stroke, atherosclerosis in other blood vessels, or who have diabetes or well-controlled hypertension.

A number of highly effective drugs (such as lipid‐lowering agents, aspirin, ACE inhibitors, beta blockers, and other anti‐hypertensive drugs) have had a substantial impact on reducing cardiovascular disease mortality

patterns: How much physical activity should I be doing?
How much exercise is needed?
Do I need to exercise a lot?
responses: Undertaking 150 minutes of moderate intensity activity a week will limit risks of developing diseases such as heart disease and diabetes
The right amount of exercise could be achieved by doing 30 minutes of activity, five days a week but could also be reached by doing shorter bouts of 10 minutes or more
To gain real benefit, adults (including older adults) should take at least 150 minutes of moderate‐intensity aerobic activity a week.

patterns: What types of activities count?
What kind of exercise should I take?
Is any type of activities okay or do I need to take specific exercise?
responses: All types of activity, provided they are of at least moderate intensity, contribute towards the 150 minutes a week and different types of physical activity benefit different body systems
In general, any moderately intense activity, such as brisk walking, will do.
Moderate exercises such as, but ot limited to, brisk walking, stair climbing or cycling are good enough to prevent cardiovascular diseases.

patterns: Is it true that some type of alcohol is good for your heart?
Can something like red wine help prevent heart disease?
Can alcohol have any benefits for your heart?
responses: Research has suggested that small amounts of alcohol may have a protective effect on your heart, but large intakes will have a detrimental effect.
While alcohol’s anti-clotting ability might protect to a limited extent against heart attack, it may increase the risk of haemorrhagic stroke
Any kind of alcohol-containing drink might have some cardiac benefit, but said benefit will be lost at high consumption.
